content.question: Which of the following best describes a difference between Eisenhower’s and Kennedy’s arguments in the excerpts?

choices.label: Eisenhower believed that the United States should invade communist countries, while Kennedy believed that the United States should establish peaceful relations with communist countries.
Eisenhower claimed that communism posed no threat to the United States, while Kennedy claimed that communism was a danger to the United States.
Kennedy called for an increase in spending on national defense, while Eisenhower cautioned against the effect of defense spending on democratic government.
Kennedy asserted that overseas allies were dispensable in the fight against communism, while Eisenhower warned that overseas allies were necessary to oppose communist aggression.

content.answer: Kennedy called for an increase in spending on national defense, while Eisenhower cautioned against the effect of defense spending on democratic government.

skill.text: Skill 3.C: Compare the arguments or main ideas of two sources.
